question_text: Which best explains why DNS can resolve any domain globally despite not relying on a single central server?
answer_options: All DNS servers maintain a complete replica of every domain
Root and TLD servers replicate all queries to regional servers
The distributed database architecture allows partial storage of global records
DNS operates in peer-to-peer mode, skipping centralized resolution
correct_answer: The distributed database architecture allows partial storage of global records
explanation: No single DNS server holds all records. Instead, the system is globally distributed, with zones delegated to appropriate authoritative servers.
